The shape reflects the tunnel entrance it is built on]] [[File:Living Roof.JPG|inline|right|thumb|The Living Roof of the California Academy of Sciences, a museum and research facility in San Francisco, California]] [[File:Kansai International Airport03s3s4410.jpg|inline|right|thumb|Kansai International Airport, Osaka, Japan (1991â1994)]] '''Renzo Piano ''' (born 14 September 1937) is an [[Italy|Italian]] [[architect]]. He is the recipient of the [[Pritzker Architecture Prize]], [[AIA Gold Medal]], [[Kyoto Prize]] and the [[Sonning Prize]]. One admirer said the "serenity of his best buildings can almost make you believe that we live in a civilised world". ==Biography== Piano was born in [[Genoa]], Italy, in 1937 and maintains a home and office (Building Workshop) in the area. He was educated and subsequently taught at the [[Politecnico di Milano]]. He graduated from the University in 1964 and began working with experimental lightweight structures and basic shelters.{{cite news|url=http://www.itnewsonline.com/showprnstory.php?storyid=31504|title=Renzo Piano: Environmentally Progressive Concept Design for Athens' Modern Urban Icon, The Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center (SNFCC)|date=2009-01-27|accessdate=2009-02-09}} From 1965 to 1970 he worked with [[Louis Kahn]] and with Makowsky. He worked together with [[Richard Rogers]] from 1971 to 1978; their most famous joint project is the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in [[Paris]] (1977). He also had a long collaboration with the engineer [[Peter Rice]]. In 1981, Piano founded the "Renzo Piano Building Workshop", employing a hundred people with offices in [[Paris]], [[Genoa]], and [[New York]]. On 18 March 2008, he became an honorary [[citizen]] of [[Sarajevo]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]].[http://www.sarajevo-x.com/clanak/080318044 Renzo Piano poÄasni graÄanin Sarajeva] Piano's recent expansion of the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] includes a {{convert|264000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} wing with {{convert|60000|sqft|m2}} of gallery space{{cite news|author=Smith, Roberta|title=A Grand and Intimate Modern Art Trove |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/14/arts/design/14inst.html|date=May 13, 2009|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-05-13}} called the Modern Wing, which opened on 16 May 2009.{{cite news|author=Ouroussof, Nicolai|title=Renzo Piano Embraces Chicago |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/14/arts/design/14muse.html|date=May 13, 2009|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-05-13}}{{cite news|author=Ouroussof, Nicolai|title=Renzo Piano Embraces Chicago (slide show)|url=http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2009/05/13/arts/20090513_INSTITUTE_SLIDESHOW_index.html|date=May 13, 2009|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-05-13}} It includes a "flying carpet", a sunscreen that hovers above the roof and a {{convert|620|ft|m|adj=on}} steel bridge connecting Millennium Park to a sculpture terrace that leads into a restaurant on the wingâs third floor.Barliant, Claire.
